# _The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

This article is about the 2001 live-action film. For the book from which it
was adapted, see [The Fellowship of the Ring](/wiki/The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring
"The Fellowship of the Ring"). For other uses, see [The Fellowship of the Ring
(disambiguation)](/wiki/The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring_\(disambiguation\) "The
Fellowship of the Ring \(disambiguation\)").

_**The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring**_ is a 2001
[epic](/wiki/Epic_film "Epic film") [adventure](/wiki/Adventure_film
"Adventure film") [fantasy film](/wiki/Fantasy_film "Fantasy film") directed
by [Peter Jackson](/wiki/Peter_Jackson "Peter Jackson") based on the [first
volume](/wiki/The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring "The Fellowship of the Ring") of [J.
R. R. Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien")'s _[The Lord of the
Rings](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings "The Lord of the Rings")_
(1954–1955).[4][5][6] It is the first instalment in _[The Lord of the Rings
series](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_\(film_series\) "The Lord of the Rings
\(film series\)")_ , and was followed by _[The Two
Towers](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Two_Towers "The Lord of the Rings:
The Two Towers")_ (2002) and _[The Return of the
King](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Return_of_the_King "The Lord of the
Rings: The Return of the King")_ (2003), based on the second and third volumes
of _The Lord of the Rings_.

Set in [Middle-earth](/wiki/Middle-earth "Middle-earth"), the story tells of
the Dark Lord [Sauron](/wiki/Sauron "Sauron") ([Sala Baker](/wiki/Sala_Baker
"Sala Baker")), who is seeking the [One Ring](/wiki/One_Ring "One Ring"). The
Ring has found its way to the young [hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") [Frodo
Baggins](/wiki/Frodo_Baggins "Frodo Baggins") ([Elijah Wood](/wiki/Elijah_Wood
"Elijah Wood")). The fate of Middle-earth hangs in the balance as Frodo and
eight companions who form the [Fellowship of the
Ring](/wiki/Fellowship_of_the_Ring_\(characters\) "Fellowship of the Ring
\(characters\)") begin their journey to [Mount Doom](/wiki/Mount_Doom "Mount
Doom") in the land of [Mordor](/wiki/Mordor "Mordor"), the only place where
the Ring can be destroyed.

Released on 10 December 2001, the film was highly acclaimed by critics and
fans alike who considered it to be a landmark in film-making and an
achievement in the fantasy film genre. It has continued to be featured on
critic lists of the [greatest fantasy films ever
made](/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best "List of films considered the
best"), as of
2017[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit).
The film earned over $871 million worldwide and became the second highest-
grossing film of 2001 in the US and worldwide (behind _[Harry Potter and the
Philosopher's Stone](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone_\(film\)
"Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone \(film\)")_).

It was nominated for thirteen [Oscars](/wiki/Academy_Awards "Academy Awards")
at the [74th Academy Awards](/wiki/74th_Academy_Awards "74th Academy Awards")
ceremony, including [Best Picture](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture
"Academy Award for Best Picture"), [Best
Director](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director "Academy Award for Best
Director"), and [Best Supporting
Actor](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor "Academy Award for Best
Supporting Actor") for McKellen, winning four for [Best
Cinematography](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Cinematography "Academy Award for
Best Cinematography"), [Best Makeup](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Makeup
"Academy Award for Best Makeup"), [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for Best
Original Score"), and [Best Visual
Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects "Academy Award for Best
Visual Effects"). It also won four [British Academy Film
Awards](/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards "British Academy Film Awards"),
including Best Film and Best Director BAFTA awards. The _Special Extended
Edition_ was released to DVD on 12 November 2002 and to [Blu-ray
Disc](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") on 28 June 2011. In 2007, _The
Fellowship of the Ring_ was voted No. 50 on the [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute")'s list of
[100 greatest American
films](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Movies_\(10th_Anniversary_Edition\)
"AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies \(10th Anniversary Edition\)"). The AFI also
voted it the second greatest fantasy film of all time during their [10 Top
10](/wiki/AFI%27s_10_Top_10 "AFI's 10 Top 10") special. The film ranks #24 on
[_Empire_](/wiki/Empire_magazine "Empire magazine")'s 2008 list of the 500
greatest movies of all time.[7]

##
Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Plot")]

In the Second Age of [Middle-earth](/wiki/Middle-earth "Middle-earth"), the
lords of [Elves](/wiki/Elf_\(Middle-earth\) "Elf \(Middle-earth\)"),
[Dwarves](/wiki/Dwarf_\(Middle-earth\) "Dwarf \(Middle-earth\)"), and
[Men](/wiki/Man_\(Middle-earth\) "Man \(Middle-earth\)") are given [Rings of
Power](/wiki/Rings_of_Power "Rings of Power"). Unbeknownst to them, the [Dark
Lord Sauron](/wiki/Sauron "Sauron") forges the [One Ring](/wiki/One_Ring "One
Ring") in [Mount Doom](/wiki/Mount_Doom "Mount Doom"), infusing into it a
great part of his power to dominate, through it and at a distance, the other
Rings, so he might conquer Middle-earth. A final alliance of men and elves
battles Sauron’s forces in [Mordor](/wiki/Mordor "Mordor"), where Prince
[Isildur](/wiki/Isildur "Isildur") of [Gondor](/wiki/Gondor "Gondor") severs
Sauron's finger, and the Ring with it, thereby destroying his physical form.
With Sauron's first defeat, the Third Age of Middle-earth begins.
Unfortunately, the Ring's influence corrupts Isildur, and, rather than destroy
the Ring, Isildur takes it for himself. Isildur is later killed by
[Orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(Middle-earth\) "Orc \(Middle-earth\)"), and the Ring is
lost for 2,500 years, until it is found by [Gollum](/wiki/Gollum "Gollum"),
who owns it for five centuries. The Ring is then found by a
[Hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") named [Bilbo Baggins](/wiki/Bilbo_Baggins
"Bilbo Baggins").

Sixty years later, Bilbo celebrates his 111th birthday in the
[Shire](/wiki/Shire_\(Middle-earth\) "Shire \(Middle-earth\)"), reuniting with
his old friend, [Gandalf the Grey](/wiki/Gandalf "Gandalf"). Bilbo reveals
that he intends to leave the Shire for one last adventure, and he leaves his
inheritance, including the Ring, to his nephew, [Frodo](/wiki/Frodo_Baggins
"Frodo Baggins"). Although Bilbo has begun to become corrupted by the Ring and
tries to keep it for himself, Gandalf intervenes. Gandalf, suspicious of the
Ring, tells Frodo to keep it secret and to keep it safe. Gandalf then
investigates the Ring, discovers its true identity, and returns to warn Frodo.
Gandalf also learns that Gollum was tortured by Orcs, and that Gollum uttered
two words during his torture: "Shire" and "Baggins." Gandalf instructs Frodo
to leave the Shire, accompanied by his gardener [Samwise
Gamgee](/wiki/Samwise_Gamgee "Samwise Gamgee"). Gandalf rides to
[Isengard](/wiki/Isengard "Isengard") to meet with fellow wizard
[Saruman](/wiki/Saruman "Saruman") the White, but learns that he has joined
forces with Sauron, who has unleashed the [Ringwraiths](/wiki/Ringwraith
"Ringwraith") to find Frodo. After a brief battle, Saruman imprisons Gandalf.
Frodo and Sam are joined by fellow Hobbits, [Merry](/wiki/Meriadoc_Brandybuck
"Meriadoc Brandybuck") and [Pippin](/wiki/Peregrin_Took "Peregrin Took"), and
they evade the Ringwraiths, arriving in [Bree](/wiki/Bree_\(Middle-earth\)
"Bree \(Middle-earth\)"), where they are meant to meet Gandalf. However,
Gandalf never arrived, and they are instead aided by a ranger named
[Strider](/wiki/Aragorn "Aragorn"), a friend of Gandalf's, who escorts them to
[Rivendell](/wiki/Rivendell "Rivendell").

The Hobbits are ambushed by the Ringwraiths, and one stabs Frodo with a cursed
[Morgul blade](/wiki/Morgul_blade "Morgul blade"). [Arwen](/wiki/Arwen
"Arwen"), an elf and Strider’s lover, comes to Frodo’s aid and successfully
takes him to Rivendell, where he is healed. Frodo meets Gandalf, who escaped
Isengard on the back of a giant [Eagle](/wiki/Eagle_\(Middle-earth\) "Eagle
\(Middle-earth\)"). Arwen’s father, [Lord Elrond,](/wiki/Elrond "Elrond")
holds a council that decides the Ring must be destroyed in Mount Doom. While
the members argue, Frodo volunteers to take the Ring, accompanied by Gandalf,
Sam, Merry, Pippin, elf [Legolas](/wiki/Legolas "Legolas"), dwarf
[Gimli](/wiki/Gimli_\(Middle-earth\) "Gimli \(Middle-earth\)"),
[Boromir](/wiki/Boromir "Boromir") of Gondor, and Strider, who is revealed to
be Aragorn, Isildur’s heir and the rightful King of Gondor. Bilbo gives Frodo
his sword, Sting. The Fellowship of the Ring sets off, but Saruman’s magic
forces them to travel through the Mines of [Moria](/wiki/Moria_\(Middle-
earth\) "Moria \(Middle-earth\)"), much to Gandalf's displeasure.

The Fellowship discovers that the dwarves within Moria have been slain, and
they are attacked by Orcs and a cave [troll](/wiki/Troll "Troll"). They defeat
them, but are confronted by an ancient demon called a [Balrog](/wiki/Balrog
"Balrog"). Gandalf casts the Balrog into a vast chasm, but it drags Gandalf
down into the darkness with it. The rest of the Fellowship, now commanded by
Aragorn, reaches [Lothlórien](/wiki/Lothl%C3%B3rien "Lothlórien"), home to
elves [Galadriel](/wiki/Galadriel "Galadriel") and [Celeborn](/wiki/Celeborn
"Celeborn"). Galadriel privately informs Frodo that only he can complete the
quest, and that one of his friends will try to take the Ring. Meanwhile,
Saruman creates an army of [Uruk-hai](/wiki/Uruk-hai "Uruk-hai") to track down
and kill the Fellowship.

The Fellowship leaves Lothlórien by river to [Parth Galen](/wiki/Parth_Galen
"Parth Galen"). Frodo wanders off and is confronted by Boromir, who tries to
take the Ring in desperation. Afraid of the Ring corrupting his friends, Frodo
decides to travel to Mordor alone. The Fellowship is then ambushed by the
Uruk-hai. Merry and Pippin are taken captive, and Boromir is mortally wounded
by the Uruk chieftain. After slaying the chieftain, Aragorn watches Boromir
die peacefully. Sam follows Frodo, accompanying him to keep his promise to
Gandalf to protect Frodo, while Aragorn, Legolas, and Gimli go to rescue Merry
and Pippin.

##
Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Cast")]

Further information: [Cast of The Lord of the Rings film
series](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_\(film_series\)#Cast "The Lord of the
Rings \(film series\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/4/40/Fellowship.JPG)](/wiki/File:Fellowship.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Fellowship.JPG "Enlarge")

The eponymous Fellowship of the Ring, from left to right: (Top row) Aragorn,
Gandalf, Legolas, Boromir, (bottom row) Sam, Frodo, Merry, Pippin, Gimli.

Before filming began on 11 October 1999, the principal actors trained for six
weeks in sword fighting (with [Bob Anderson](/wiki/Bob_Anderson_\(fencer\)
"Bob Anderson \(fencer\)")), riding and boating. Jackson hoped such activities
would allow the cast to bond so chemistry would be evident on screen as well
as getting them used to life in [Wellington](/wiki/Wellington
"Wellington").[8] They were also trained to pronounce Tolkien's verses
properly.[9] After the shoot, the nine cast members playing the Fellowship got
a tattoo of the English word "nine" written in [Tengwar](/wiki/Tengwar
"Tengwar"), with the exception of [John Rhys-Davies](/wiki/John_Rhys-Davies
"John Rhys-Davies"), whose stunt double got the tattoo instead.[10] The film
is noted for having an [ensemble cast](/wiki/Ensemble_cast "Ensemble
cast"),[11] and some of the cast and their respective characters include:

  * [Elijah Wood](/wiki/Elijah_Wood "Elijah Wood") as [Frodo Baggins](/wiki/Frodo_Baggins "Frodo Baggins"): a young [hobbit](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") who inherits the [One Ring](/wiki/One_Ring "One Ring") from his uncle Bilbo. Wood was the first actor to be cast on 7 July 1999.[12] Wood was a fan of the book, and he sent in an audition dressed as Frodo, reading lines from the novel.[13] Wood was selected from 150 actors who auditioned,[14] including [Jake Gyllenhaal](/wiki/Jake_Gyllenhaal "Jake Gyllenhaal").[15]
  * [Ian McKellen](/wiki/Ian_McKellen "Ian McKellen") as [Gandalf the Grey](/wiki/Gandalf "Gandalf"): an [Istari wizard](/wiki/Wizard_\(Middle-earth\) "Wizard \(Middle-earth\)") and mentor to Frodo. [Sean Connery](/wiki/Sean_Connery "Sean Connery") was approached for the role, but did not understand the plot,[13] while [Patrick Stewart](/wiki/Patrick_Stewart "Patrick Stewart") turned it down as he disliked the script.[16] Before being cast, McKellen had to sort his schedule with [20th Century Fox](/wiki/20th_Century_Fox "20th Century Fox") as there was a two-month overlap with _[X-Men](/wiki/X-Men_\(film\) "X-Men \(film\)")_.[14] He enjoyed playing Gandalf the Grey more than his transformed state in the next two films,[10] and based his accent on Tolkien. Unlike his on-screen character, McKellen did not spend much time with the actors playing the Hobbits; instead he worked with their scale doubles.[8]
  * [Sean Astin](/wiki/Sean_Astin "Sean Astin") as [Samwise "Sam" Gamgee](/wiki/Samwise_Gamgee "Samwise Gamgee"): a hobbit gardener and Frodo's best friend. Astin, who had recently become a father, bonded with the 18-year-old Wood in a protective manner, which mirrored Sam's relationship with Frodo.[8]
  * [Viggo Mortensen](/wiki/Viggo_Mortensen "Viggo Mortensen") as [Aragorn II Elessar](/wiki/Aragorn "Aragorn"): a [Dúnedain](/wiki/D%C3%BAnedain "Dúnedain") [ranger](/wiki/Ranger_\(Middle-earth\) "Ranger \(Middle-earth\)"), the descendant of Isildur, and heir to [Gondor](/wiki/Gondor "Gondor")'s throne. [Daniel Day-Lewis](/wiki/Daniel_Day-Lewis "Daniel Day-Lewis") was offered the part at the beginning of pre-production, but turned it down.[17] [Nicolas Cage](/wiki/Nicolas_Cage "Nicolas Cage") also received an offer, declining because of "family obligations",[18] while [Vin Diesel](/wiki/Vin_Diesel "Vin Diesel"), a fan of the book, auditioned for Aragorn. [Stuart Townsend](/wiki/Stuart_Townsend "Stuart Townsend") was cast in the role, before being replaced during filming when Jackson realised he was too young.[13] [Russell Crowe](/wiki/Russell_Crowe "Russell Crowe") was considered as a replacement, but he turned it down after taking what he thought to be a similar role in _[Gladiator](/wiki/Gladiator_\(2000_film\) "Gladiator \(2000 film\)")_.[13] Day-Lewis was offered the role for a second time, but declined again.[17] Executive Producer [Mark Ordesky](/wiki/Mark_Ordesky "Mark Ordesky") saw Mortensen in a play. Mortensen's son, a fan of the book, convinced him to take the role.[8] Mortensen read the book on the plane, received a crash course lesson in fencing from Bob Anderson and began filming the scenes on Weathertop.[19] Mortensen became a hit with the crew by patching up his costume[20] and carrying his "hero" sword around with him off-camera.[8]
  * [Billy Boyd](/wiki/Billy_Boyd_\(actor\) "Billy Boyd \(actor\)") as [Peregrin "Pippin" Took](/wiki/Peregrin_Took "Peregrin Took"): a hobbit who travels with the Fellowship on their journey to Mordor.
  * [Dominic Monaghan](/wiki/Dominic_Monaghan "Dominic Monaghan") as [Meriadoc "Merry" Brandybuck](/wiki/Meriadoc_Brandybuck "Meriadoc Brandybuck"): a distant cousin of Frodo. Monaghan was cast as Merry after auditioning for Frodo.[13]
  * [John Rhys-Davies](/wiki/John_Rhys-Davies "John Rhys-Davies") as [Gimli](/wiki/Gimli_\(Middle-earth\) "Gimli \(Middle-earth\)"): a [dwarf](/wiki/Dwarf_\(Middle-earth\) "Dwarf \(Middle-earth\)") warrior who accompanies the Fellowship to Mordor after they set out from [Rivendell](/wiki/Rivendell "Rivendell") and a descendant of Durin's Folk. [Billy Connolly](/wiki/Billy_Connolly "Billy Connolly"), who was considered for the part of Gimli, later portrayed [Dáin II Ironfoot](/wiki/D%C3%A1in_II_Ironfoot "Dáin II Ironfoot") in [Peter Jackson](/wiki/Peter_Jackson "Peter Jackson")'s [_The Hobbit_ film trilogy](/wiki/The_Hobbit_\(film_series\) "The Hobbit \(film series\)").[13] Rhys-Davies wore heavy prosthetics to play Gimli, which limited his vision, and eventually developed [eczema](/wiki/Eczema "Eczema") around his eyes.[8]
  * [Orlando Bloom](/wiki/Orlando_Bloom "Orlando Bloom") as [Legolas Greenleaf](/wiki/Legolas "Legolas"): a prince of the elves' [Woodland Realm](/wiki/Mirkwood "Mirkwood") and a skilled archer. Bloom initially auditioned for [Faramir](/wiki/Faramir "Faramir"), who appears in the second film, a role which went to [David Wenham](/wiki/David_Wenham "David Wenham").[13]
  * [Sean Bean](/wiki/Sean_Bean "Sean Bean") as [Boromir](/wiki/Boromir "Boromir"): a prince of the [Stewards of Gondor](/wiki/Stewards_of_Gondor "Stewards of Gondor") who journeys with the Fellowship towards Mordor. [Bruce Willis](/wiki/Bruce_Willis "Bruce Willis"), a fan of the book, expressed interest in the role, while [Liam Neeson](/wiki/Liam_Neeson "Liam Neeson") was sent the script, but passed.[13]
  * [Ian Holm](/wiki/Ian_Holm "Ian Holm") as [Bilbo Baggins](/wiki/Bilbo_Baggins "Bilbo Baggins"): Frodo's uncle who gives him the Ring after he decides to retire to Rivendell. Holm previously played Frodo in a [1981 radio adaption of _The Lord of the Rings_](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_\(1981_radio_series\) "The Lord of the Rings \(1981 radio series\)"), and was cast as Bilbo after Jackson remembered his performance.[13] [Sylvester McCoy](/wiki/Sylvester_McCoy "Sylvester McCoy"), who would later play Radagast the Brown in _[The Hobbit](/wiki/The_Hobbit_\(film_series\) "The Hobbit \(film series\)")_ , was contacted about playing the role, and was kept in place as a potential Bilbo for six months before Jackson went with Holm.[21]
  * [Liv Tyler](/wiki/Liv_Tyler "Liv Tyler") as [Arwen Undomiel](/wiki/Arwen "Arwen"): a beautiful [half-elf](/wiki/Elf_\(Middle-earth\) "Elf \(Middle-earth\)") princess of Rivendell and Aragorn's lover. The filmmakers approached Tyler after seeing her performance in _[Plunkett& Macleane](/wiki/Plunkett_%26_Macleane "Plunkett & Macleane")_, and [New Line Cinema](/wiki/New_Line_Cinema "New Line Cinema") leaped at the opportunity of having one Hollywood star in the film. Actress [Helena Bonham Carter](/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter "Helena Bonham Carter") had expressed interest in the role.[13] Peter Jackson wanted to cast [Uma Thurman](/wiki/Uma_Thurman "Uma Thurman") as Arwen, but Thurman pulled out due to pregnancy, Tyler came to shoot on short occasions, unlike the rest of the actors. She was one of the last actors to be cast, on 25 August 1999.[22]
  * [Cate Blanchett](/wiki/Cate_Blanchett "Cate Blanchett") as [Galadriel](/wiki/Galadriel "Galadriel"): the elven co-ruler of [Lothlórien](/wiki/Lothl%C3%B3rien "Lothlórien") alongside her husband Celeborn. Peter Jackson wanted to cast [Lucy Lawless](/wiki/Lucy_Lawless "Lucy Lawless") as Galadriel, but she declined due to pregnancy.[23]
  * [Christopher Lee](/wiki/Christopher_Lee "Christopher Lee") as [Saruman the White](/wiki/Saruman "Saruman"): the fallen head of the Istari Order who succumbs to Sauron's will through his use of the _[palantír](/wiki/Palant%C3%ADr "Palantír")_. Lee was a major fan of the book, and read it once a year. He had also met [J. R. R. Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien").[19] He originally auditioned for Gandalf, but was judged too old.[13]
  * [Hugo Weaving](/wiki/Hugo_Weaving "Hugo Weaving") as [Elrond](/wiki/Elrond "Elrond"): the elven Lord of Rivendell who leads the [Council of Elrond](/wiki/Council_of_Elrond "Council of Elrond"), which ultimately decides to destroy the Ring. [David Bowie](/wiki/David_Bowie "David Bowie") expressed interest in the role, but Jackson stated, "To have a famous, beloved character and a famous star colliding is slightly uncomfortable."[14]
  * [Sala Baker](/wiki/Sala_Baker "Sala Baker") as [Sauron](/wiki/Sauron "Sauron"): the Dark Lord of [Mordor](/wiki/Mordor "Mordor") and the Ring's true master who manifests as an [Eye](/wiki/Eye_of_Sauron "Eye of Sauron") after the destruction of his physical form. Originally hired as one of the several [stunt performers](/wiki/Stunt_performer "Stunt performer") for the film trilogy, Baker ended up landing the role. In addition, he went on to play several Orcs as well.
  * [Andy Serkis](/wiki/Andy_Serkis "Andy Serkis") as [Gollum](/wiki/Gollum "Gollum") voice and [motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture"): a wretched hobbit-like creature whose mind was poisoned over centuries by the Ring.
  * [David Weatherley](/wiki/David_Weatherley "David Weatherley") as [Barliman Butterbur](/wiki/Barliman_Butterbur "Barliman Butterbur"), proprietor in Bree
  * [Lawrence Makoare](/wiki/Lawrence_Makoare "Lawrence Makoare") as [Lurtz](/wiki/List_of_Middle-earth_Orcs#Lurtz "List of Middle-earth Orcs"): the commander of Saruman's Orc forces;
  * [Marton Csokas](/wiki/Marton_Csokas "Marton Csokas") as [Celeborn](/wiki/Celeborn "Celeborn"): the elven co-ruler of [Lothlórien](/wiki/Lothl%C3%B3rien "Lothlórien") alongside his wife Galadriel;
  * [Craig Parker](/wiki/Craig_Parker "Craig Parker") as [Haldir](/wiki/Haldir_of_L%C3%B3rien "Haldir of Lórien"): the leader of the Galadhrim warriors guarding the border of Lothlórien;
  * [Mark Ferguson](/wiki/Mark_Ferguson "Mark Ferguson") as [Ereinion Gil-galad](/wiki/Gil-galad "Gil-galad"), the last Elven-King of [Noldor](/wiki/Noldor "Noldor");
  * [Peter McKenzie](/wiki/Peter_McKenzie_\(actor\) "Peter McKenzie \(actor\)") as [Elendil the Tall](/wiki/Elendil "Elendil"): the last High King of Arnor and Gondor;
  * [Harry Sinclair](/wiki/Harry_Sinclair "Harry Sinclair") as [Isildur](/wiki/Isildur "Isildur"): Elendil's son and Aragorn's ancestor who originally defeated Sauron.
  * [Peter Jackson](/wiki/Peter_Jackson "Peter Jackson") as Albert Dreary: a man of Bree.

## Comparison with the source
material[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Comparison with the source material")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Unico_Anello.png/170px-
Unico_Anello.png)](/wiki/File:Unico_Anello.png)

[](/wiki/File:Unico_Anello.png "Enlarge")

The inscriptions on the Ring

Jackson, Walsh and Boyens made numerous changes to the story, for purposes of
pacing and character development. Jackson said his main desire was to make a
film focused primarily on Frodo and the Ring, the "backbone" of the story.[24]
The prologue condenses Tolkien's backstory, in which The Last Alliance's
seven-year siege of the [Barad-dûr](/wiki/Barad-d%C3%BBr "Barad-dûr") is a
single battle, where Sauron is shown to explode, though Tolkien only said his
spirit flees.[25]

Events from the book are condensed or omitted altogether at the beginning of
the film. The time between Gandalf leaving the Ring to Frodo and returning to
reveal its inscription, which is 17 years in the book, is compressed for
timing reasons.[26] Frodo also spends a few months preparing to move to
Buckland, on the eastern border of the Shire. This move is omitted, and
associated events, including the involvement of Merry and Pippin, are changed
and combined with him setting out for Bree. Characters such as [Tom
Bombadil](/wiki/Tom_Bombadil "Tom Bombadil") and the incidents in the Old
Forest and the Barrow Downs are left out to simplify the plot and increase the
threat of the [Ringwraiths](/wiki/Nazg%C3%BBl "Nazgûl"). Such sequences are
left out to make time to introduce Saruman, who doesn't appear in the book
until Gandalf's account at the Council of Elrond. While some characters are
left out, some are referenced such as Tom, Bert, and William to show how _The
Hobbit_ and _The Lord of the Rings_ series intertwine. Saruman's role is
enhanced: he is to blame for the blizzard on Caradhras, a role taken from
Sauron and/or Caradhras itself in the book. Gandalf's capture by Saruman is
also expanded with a fight sequence.

The role of [Barliman Butterbur](/wiki/Barliman_Butterbur "Barliman
Butterbur") at the Prancing Pony is largely removed for time and dramatic
flow. In the film Pippin is seen to identify Frodo explicitly with the phrase
"why there's Baggins over there" whereas in the book Pippin is only telling
the tale of Bilbo's disappearance when Strider tells Frodo to create a
distraction, which he does by singing a song.

The events at Weathertop were also altered. The location of the fight against
the Ringwraiths was changed to the ruins on top of the hill rather than a
campsite at its base. When Frodo was stabbed in the book, the party spent two
weeks travelling to Rivendell, but in the film this is shortened to less than
a week, with Frodo's condition worsening at a commensurately greater rate.
[Arwen](/wiki/Arwen "Arwen") was given a greater role in the film,
accompanying Frodo all the way to Rivendell, while in the book Frodo faced the
Ringwraiths alone at the [Ford of Bruinen](/wiki/Bruinen "Bruinen"). The
character of [Glorfindel](/wiki/Glorfindel "Glorfindel") was omitted entirely
and his scenes were also given to Arwen. She was tacitly credited with the
river rising against the Ringwraiths, which was the work of her father
[Elrond](/wiki/Elrond "Elrond") with aid from [Gandalf](/wiki/Gandalf
"Gandalf") in the book.

A significant new addition is Aragorn's self-doubt, which causes him to
hesitate to claim the kingship of Gondor. This element is not present in the
book, where Aragorn intends to claim the throne at an appropriate time. In the
book Narsil is reforged immediately when he joins the Fellowship, but this
event is held over until _[Return of the
King](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Return_of_the_King "The Lord of the
Rings: The Return of the King")_ in film to symbolically coincide with his
acceptance of his title. These elements were added because Peter Jackson
believed that each character should be forced to grow or change over the
course of the story.

[Elrond](/wiki/Elrond "Elrond")'s character gained an adversarial edge; he
expresses doubts in the strength of Men to resist Sauron's evil after
Isildur's failure to destroy the ring as depicted in the prologue. Jackson
also shortens the Council of Elrond by spreading its exposition into earlier
parts of the film. Elrond's counsellor, [Erestor](/wiki/Erestor "Erestor")—who
suggested the Ring be given to [Tom Bombadil](/wiki/Tom_Bombadil "Tom
Bombadil")—was completely absent from this scene. Gimli's father,
[Glóin](/wiki/Gl%C3%B3in "Glóin"), was also deemed unnecessary. In addition,
the movie makes it seem by chance that the Fellowship is made of nine
companions, whereas in the book Elrond suggests there be nine in the
fellowship in response to the nine [Nazgûl](/wiki/Nazg%C3%BBl "Nazgûl").

The tone of the Moria sequence was altered. In the book, following the defeat
on the Caradhras road, Gandalf advocates the Moria road against the resistance
of the rest of the Fellowship (save Gimli), suggesting "there is a hope that
Moria is still free...there is even a chance that Dwarves are there," though
no one seems to think this likely. Frodo proposes they take a company vote,
but the discovery of [Wargs](/wiki/Warg#J._R._R._Tolkien.27s_wargs "Warg") on
their trail forces them to accept Gandalf's proposal. They only realise the
Dwarves are all dead once they reach [Balin](/wiki/Balin_\(Middle-earth\)
"Balin \(Middle-earth\)")'s tomb. The filmmakers chose instead for Gandalf to
resist the Moria plan as a [foreshadowing](/wiki/Foreshadowing
"Foreshadowing") device. Gandalf says to Gimli he would prefer not to enter
Moria, and Saruman is shown to be aware of Gandalf's hesitance, revealing an
illustration of the Balrog in one of his books. The corpses of the dwarves are
instantly shown as the Fellowship enter Moria.[27] One detail that many
critics commented upon is the fact that, in the novel, Pippin tosses a mere
pebble into the well in Moria ("They then hear what sounds like a hammer
tapping in the distance"), whereas in the film, he knocks an entire skeleton
in ("Next, the skeleton ... falls down the well, also dragging down a chain
and bucket. The noise is incredible."[28])[29][30][31][32]

In terms of dramatic structure, the book simply ends; there is no climax,
because Tolkien wrote the "trilogy" as a single story published in three
volumes. Jackson's version incorporates the first chapter of '"The Two Towers"
and makes its events, told in real time instead of flashback, simultaneous
with the Breaking of the Fellowship. This finale is played as a climactic
battle, into which he introduces the Uruk-hai referred to as Lurtz in the
script. In the book, Boromir is unable to tell Aragorn which hobbits were
kidnapped by the orcs before he dies. From there, Aragorn deduces Frodo's
intentions when he notices that a boat is missing and Sam's pack is gone. In
the film, Aragorn and Frodo have a scene together in which Frodo's intentions
are explicitly stated.

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Production")]

###
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Development")]

[Peter Jackson](/wiki/Peter_Jackson "Peter Jackson") began working with
[Christian Rivers](/wiki/Christian_Rivers "Christian Rivers") to
[storyboard](/wiki/Storyboard "Storyboard") the series in August 1997, as well
as getting [Richard Taylor](/wiki/Richard_Taylor_\(filmmaker\) "Richard Taylor
\(filmmaker\)") and [Weta Workshop](/wiki/Weta_Workshop "Weta Workshop") to
begin creating his interpretation of Middle-earth.[33] Jackson told them to
make Middle-earth as plausible and believable as possible, to think of Middle-
earth in a historical manner.[34]

In November,[34] [Alan Lee](/wiki/Alan_Lee_\(illustrator\) "Alan Lee
\(illustrator\)") and [John Howe](/wiki/John_Howe_\(illustrator\) "John Howe
\(illustrator\)") became the film trilogy's primary conceptual designers,
having had previous experience as illustrators for the book and various other
tie-ins. Lee worked for the Art Department creating places such as
[Rivendell](/wiki/Rivendell "Rivendell"), [Isengard](/wiki/Isengard
"Isengard"), [Moria](/wiki/Moria_\(Middle-earth\) "Moria \(Middle-earth\)")
and [Lothlórien](/wiki/Lothl%C3%B3rien "Lothlórien"), giving [Art
Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") and [geometry](/wiki/Geometry
"Geometry") influences to the Elves and Dwarves respectively.[34][35] Though
Howe contributed with Bag End and the [Argonath](/wiki/Argonath
"Argonath"),[34][35] he focused working on armour having studied it all his
life.[36] Weta and the Art Department continued to design, with [Grant
Major](/wiki/Grant_Major "Grant Major") turning the Art Department's designs
into architecture, and [Dan Hennah](/wiki/Dan_Hennah "Dan Hennah") scouting
locations.[34] On 1 April 1999, [Ngila Dickson](/wiki/Ngila_Dickson "Ngila
Dickson") joined the crew as costume designer. She and 40 seamstresses would
create 19,000 costumes, 40 per version for the actor and their doubles, ageing
and wearing them out for impression of age.[20]

### Special
effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Special effects")]

_The Fellowship of the Ring_ makes extensive use of digital, practical and
make-up special effects throughout. One noticeable illusion that appears in
almost every scene involves setting a proper scale so that the characters are
all the correct height. Elijah Wood, who plays Frodo, is 5 ft 6 in (1.68 m)
tall in real life, but the character of Frodo Baggins is barely four feet in
height. Many different tricks were used to depict the hobbits (and Gimli the
Dwarf) as being of diminutive stature. (In a happy coincidence, John-Rhys
Davies – who played Gimli – is as tall compared to the Hobbit actors as his
character needed to be compared to theirs, so he did not need to be filmed
separately as a third variation of height, and is quite taller than Orlando
Bloom, who played Legolas.) Large- and small-scale doubles were used in
certain scenes, while entire duplicates of certain sets (including [Bag
End](/wiki/Bag_End "Bag End") in Hobbiton) were built at two different scales,
so that the characters would appear to be the appropriate size. At one point
in the film, Frodo runs along a corridor in Bag End, followed by Gandalf.
Elijah Wood and Ian McKellen were filmed in separate versions of the same
corridor, built at two different scales, and a fast camera pan conceals the
edit between the two. [Forced perspective](/wiki/Forced_perspective "Forced
perspective") was also employed, so that it would look as though the short
Hobbits were interacting with taller [Men](/wiki/Man_\(Middle-earth\) "Man
\(Middle-earth\)") and Elves. Even the simple use of kneeling down, to the
filmmakers' surprise, turned out to be an effective method in creating the
illusion.

For the battle between the Last Alliance and Sauron's forces that begins the
film, an elaborate [CGI](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-generated
imagery") animation system, called [MASSIVE](/wiki/MASSIVE_\(software\)
"MASSIVE \(software\)"), was developed by [Stephen
Regelous](/wiki/Stephen_Regelous "Stephen Regelous"); it allowed thousands of
individual animated "characters" in the program to act independently. This
helped give the illusion of realism to the battle sequences. The "Making of"
Lord of the Rings DVD reports some interesting initial problems: in the first
execution of a battle between groups of characters, the wrong groups attacked
each other. In another early demo, some of the warriors at the edge of the
field could be seen running away. They were initially moving in the wrong
direction, and had been programmed to keep running until they encountered an
enemy.

The digital creatures were important due to Jackson's requirement of
biological plausibility. Their surface was scanned from large
[maquettes](/wiki/Maquette "Maquette") before numerous digital details of
their skeletons and muscles were added. In the case of the Balrog, Gray
Horsfield created a system that copied recorded imagery of fire.

###
Score[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Score")]

Main article: [The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring
(soundtrack)](/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring_\(soundtrack\)
"The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring \(soundtrack\)")

See also: [Music of The Lord of the Rings film
series](/wiki/Music_of_The_Lord_of_the_Rings_film_series "Music of The Lord of
the Rings film series")

The [musical score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") for _The Lord of the Rings_
films was composed by [Howard Shore](/wiki/Howard_Shore "Howard Shore"). It
was performed by the 100-strong [New Zealand Symphony
Orchestra](/wiki/New_Zealand_Symphony_Orchestra "New Zealand Symphony
Orchestra"), the [London Philharmonic
Orchestra](/wiki/London_Philharmonic_Orchestra "London Philharmonic
Orchestra"), the [London Voices](/wiki/London_Voices "London Voices"), The
London Oratory School Schola, and the Maori Samoan Choir, and featured several
vocal soloists. Shore wrote almost four hours of finalised music for the film
(of which just over three hours are used as underscore), featuring a number of
non-orchestral instruments, and a large number (49-62) of
[leitmotives](/wiki/Leitmotif "Leitmotif").

Two original songs, "[Aníron](/wiki/An%C3%ADron "Aníron")" and the end title
theme "[May It Be](/wiki/May_It_Be "May It Be")", were composed and sung by
[Enya](/wiki/Enya "Enya"), who allowed her label, [Reprise
Records](/wiki/Reprise_Records "Reprise Records"), to release the soundtrack
to this and its two sequels. In addition to these songs, Shore composed "[In
Dreams](/wiki/In_Dreams_\(Howard_Shore_song\) "In Dreams \(Howard Shore
song\)")", which was sung by Edward Ross of the London Oratory School Schola.

##
Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Release")]

A special behind-the-scenes trailer was released in 2000. Two teasers were
shown before _[Spy Kids](/wiki/Spy_Kids "Spy Kids")_ and _[Pearl Harbor
(film)](/wiki/Pearl_Harbor_\(film\) "Pearl Harbor \(film\)")_. The final
trailer was with the television premiere of
_[Angel](/wiki/Angel_\(1999_TV_series\) "Angel \(1999 TV series\)")_ , _[Harry
Potter and the Philosopher's
Stone](/wiki/Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher%27s_Stone_\(film\) "Harry Potter
and the Philosopher's Stone \(film\)")_, and on the DVD and VHS of _[Rush Hour
2](/wiki/Rush_Hour_2 "Rush Hour 2")_.

### Home
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Home media")]

_The Fellowship of the Ring_ was released on [VHS](/wiki/VHS "VHS") and DVD in
August 2002.

#### Theatrical and extended
release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Theatrical and extended release")]

In November 2002, an extended edition was released on VHS and DVD, with 30
minutes of new material, added special effects and music, plus 20 minutes of
fan-club credits, totalling to 228 minutes.[39][40] The DVD set included four
commentaries and over three hours of supplementary material.

In August 2006, a limited edition of _The Fellowship of the Ring_ was released
on DVD. The set included both the film's theatrical and extended editions on a
[double-sided disc](/wiki/DVD-9 "DVD-9") along with all-new bonus material.

#### Blu-ray
edition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Blu-ray edition")]

The theatrical [Blu-ray](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc") version of _The
Lord of the Rings_ was released in the United States in April 2010. There were
two separate sets: one with digital copies and one without.[41] The individual
Blu-ray disc of _The Fellowship of the Ring_ was released in September 2010
with the same special features as the complete trilogy release, except there
was no digital copy.[42]

The extended Blu-ray editions were released in the US in June 2011.[43] This
version has a runtime of 238 minutes[40][44] (the extended editions include
the names of all fan club members at the time of their release; the additional
9 minutes in the Blu-ray version are because of expanded member rolls, not any
additional story material).

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box
office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Box office")]

_The Fellowship of the Ring_ was released on 19 December 2001 in 3,359 cinemas
where it grossed $47.2 million on its opening weekend. The world premiere was
held at the [Odeon Leicester Square](/wiki/Odeon_Leicester_Square "Odeon
Leicester Square") in London. It went on to make $314.7 million in North
America and $555.9 million in the rest of the world for a worldwide total of
$870.7 million.[45] [Box Office Mojo](/wiki/Box_Office_Mojo "Box Office Mojo")
estimates that the film sold over 54 million tickets in the US in its initial
theatrical run.[46]

### Critical
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Critical response")]

_The Fellowship of the Ring_ was acclaimed by film critics and was one of
2001's best reviewed films.[47] The film holds a 91% approval rating on
aggregate review site [Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten
Tomatoes") based on 227 reviews and an average score of 8.2/10. The site's
main consensus reads "Full of eye-popping special effects, and featuring a
pitch-perfect cast, _The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring_ brings
J.R.R. Tolkien's classic to vivid life".[48] The film holds a score of 92 out
of 100 on [Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic") based on 34 reviews,
indicating "universal acclaim".[49]

[Roger Ebert](/wiki/Roger_Ebert "Roger Ebert") gave the film three out of four
stars and stating that while it is not "a true visualization of Tolkien's
Middle-earth", it is "a work for, and of, our times. It will be embraced, I
suspect, by many Tolkien fans and take on aspects of a cult. It is a candidate
for many Oscars. It is an awesome production in its daring and breadth, and
there are small touches that are just right".[50] _[USA Today](/wiki/USA_Today
"USA Today")_ also gave the film three out of four stars and wrote, "this
movie version of a beloved book should please devotees as well as the
uninitiated".[51] In his review for _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ , [Elvis
Mitchell](/wiki/Elvis_Mitchell "Elvis Mitchell") wrote, "The playful
spookiness of Mr. Jackson's direction provides a lively, light touch, a
gesture that doesn't normally come to mind when Tolkien's name is
mentioned".[52] _[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly
"Entertainment Weekly")_ magazine gave the film an "A" rating and Lisa
Schwarzbaum wrote, "The cast take to their roles with becoming modesty,
certainly, but Jackson also makes it easy for them: His _Fellowship_ flows,
never lingering for the sake of admiring its own beauty ... Every detail of
which engrossed me. I may have never turned a page of Tolkien, but I know
enchantment when I see it".[53]

In her review for _[The Washington Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The
Washington Post")_ , Rita Kempley praised the cast, in particular, "Mortensen,
as Strider, is a revelation, not to mention downright gorgeous. And McKellen,
carrying the burden of thousands of years' worth of the fight against evil, is
positively Merlinesque".[54] _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time
\(magazine\)")_ magazine's Richard Corliss praised Jackson's work: "His movie
achieves what the best fairy tales do: the creation of an alternate world,
plausible and persuasive, where the young — and not only the young — can lose
themselves. And perhaps, in identifying with the little Hobbit that could,
find their better selves".[55] In his review for _[The Village
Voice](/wiki/The_Village_Voice "The Village Voice")_ , [J.
Hoberman](/wiki/J._Hoberman "J. Hoberman") wrote, "Peter Jackson's adaptation
is certainly successful on its own terms".[56] _[Rolling
Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ magazine's [Peter
Travers](/wiki/Peter_Travers "Peter Travers") wrote, "It's emotion that makes
_Fellowship_ stick hard in the memory... Jackson deserves to revel in his
success. He's made a three-hour film that leaves you wanting more".[57]
However, in his review for _[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_
, Peter Bradshaw wrote, "there is a strange paucity of plot complication, an
absence of anything unfolding, all the more disconcerting because of the
clotted and indigestible mythic back story that we have to wade through before
anything happens at all".[58]

In [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore") polls conducted during the
opening weekend, cinema audiences gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an
A+ to F scale.[59]

###
Accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Accolades")]

Main article: [List of accolades received by The Lord of the Rings film
series](/wiki/List_of_accolades_received_by_The_Lord_of_the_Rings_film_series
"List of accolades received by The Lord of the Rings film series")

In [2002](/wiki/74th_Academy_Awards "74th Academy Awards"), the film won four
[Academy Awards](/wiki/Academy_Award "Academy Award") from thirteen
nominations.[60] The winning categories were for [Best
Cinematography](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Cinematography "Academy Award for
Best Cinematography"), [Best Visual
Effects](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Visual_Effects "Academy Award for Best
Visual Effects"), [Best
Makeup](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Makeup_and_Hairstyling "Academy Award for
Best Makeup and Hairstyling"), and [Best Original
Score](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Score "Academy Award for Best
Original Score"). It was also nominated for [Best Actor in a Supporting
Role](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Supporting_Actor "Academy Award for Best
Supporting Actor") ([Ian McKellen](/wiki/Ian_McKellen "Ian McKellen")), [Best
Art Direction](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Production_Design "Academy Award
for Best Production Design"), [Best
Director](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Director "Academy Award for Best
Director"), [Best Film Editing](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Film_Editing
"Academy Award for Best Film Editing"), [Best Original
Song](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Original_Song "Academy Award for Best
Original Song") ([Enya](/wiki/Enya "Enya"), [Nicky Ryan](/wiki/Nicky_Ryan
"Nicky Ryan") and [Roma Ryan](/wiki/Roma_Ryan "Roma Ryan") for "[May It
Be](/wiki/May_It_Be "May It Be")"), [Best
Picture](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Picture "Academy Award for Best
Picture"), [Best Sound](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Sound "Academy Award for
Best Sound") ([Christopher Boyes](/wiki/Christopher_Boyes "Christopher
Boyes"), [Michael Semanick](/wiki/Michael_Semanick "Michael Semanick"),
[Gethin Creagh](/wiki/Gethin_Creagh "Gethin Creagh") and [Hammond
Peek](/wiki/Hammond_Peek "Hammond Peek")), [Best Costume
Design](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Costume_Design "Academy Award for Best
Costume Design") and [Best Adapted
Screenplay](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Writing_\(Adapted_Screenplay\)
"Academy Award for Best Writing \(Adapted Screenplay\)").

As of January
2014[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Fellowship_of_the_Ring&action=edit),
it is the 31st highest-grossing film worldwide, with US$871,530,324 in
worldwide theatrical box office receipts.[3]

The film won the 2002 [Hugo Award for Best Dramatic
Presentation](/wiki/Hugo_Award_for_Best_Dramatic_Presentation "Hugo Award for
Best Dramatic Presentation"). It also won
_[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(film_magazine\) "Empire \(film magazine\)")_ readers'
Best Film award, as well as five
[BAFTAs](/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts "British Academy of
Film and Television Arts"), including [Best
Film](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Film "BAFTA Award for Best Film"), the [David
Lean](/wiki/David_Lean "David Lean") Award for [Best
Direction](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Direction "BAFTA Award for Best
Direction"), the Audience Award (voted for by the public), [Best Special
Effects](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Special_Visual_Effects "BAFTA Award for
Best Special Visual Effects"), and [Best Make-
up](/wiki/BAFTA_Award_for_Best_Makeup_and_Hair "BAFTA Award for Best Makeup
and Hair"). The film was nominated for an [MTV Movie Award for Best
Fight](/wiki/MTV_Movie_Award_for_Best_Fight "MTV Movie Award for Best Fight")
between Gandalf and Saruman.

In June 2008, AFI revealed its "[10 Top 10](/wiki/AFI%27s_10_Top_10 "AFI's 10
Top 10")"—the ten best films in ten "classic" American film genres—after
polling over 1,500 people from the creative community. _The Fellowship of the
Ring_ was acknowledged as the second best film in the fantasy genre.[61][62]
The film was also listed as the 50th best film in the 2007 list [AFI's 100
Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary
Edition)](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Movies_\(10th_Anniversary_Edition\)
"AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies \(10th Anniversary Edition\)").
